Graphical abstract The effect of a copper modifier on physicochemical properties of coprecipitated precursors and final Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalysts for benzene to cyclohexane hydrogenation was investigated. Based on the studies of physicochemical properties, the influence of copper on the catalytic activity and selectivity of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 systems was discussed. The addition of copper resulted in a decrease of the specific and nickel surface area, improvement of the selectivity and a slight decrease of the benzene hydrogenation activity compared to the reference catalyst. A decrease of methylcyclopentane and methylcyclohexane by-products formation on the surface of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalyst containing 10–17wt% CuO by, respectively, 70% and 10% was observed. The results reveal a distinct, beneficial effect of the Ni/Al2O3 modification by copper on the catalyst selectivity. However, this effect depends on temperature and is limited to ca. 20wt% CuO, above this content the activity was found to decrease considerably. Keywords Benzene hydrogenation Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalyst Selectivity enhancement Surface segregation 1 Introduction The catalytic hydrogenation of benzene to cyclohexane is one of the stages in caprolactam production process [1,2]. Due to the high exothermic effect, the process is usually carried out in a series of two tubular reactors thermostated with boiling water. In the first stage the process runs under hydrogen lean conditions, at pressures in the range 0.2–0.3MPa. Such conditions allow the maintenance of the process temperature in the range up to 250°C and hamper the hydrogenolysis of benzene to methane and formation of other byproducts (methylcyclopentane – MCP, methylcyclohexane – MCH) that in consequence leads to higher hydrogenation selectivity. The second stage is carried out under hydrogen-rich conditions, at pressures in the range 0.6–1.2MPa, resulting in a high degree of benzene conversion [2]. The Ni/Al2O3 or Ni/SiO2 catalysts [3] with a relatively high content of nickel oxide (40–60 wt%), in the form of pellets, balls or extrudates are most often applied in the industrial practice. The requirements for benzene hydrogenation catalyst include high activity, mechanical strength, stability and coke resistance. These features depend on the nickel content [4] and dispersion [5], addition of promoters, support type [6–9] and preparation technique [10]. A particular requirement for benzene hydrogenation catalysts is their high selectivity. In the literature there have been many contributions indicating some possibilities of the selectivity improvement via an addition of promoters to nickel catalysts. Moreover, the literature data indicate a beneficial effect of copper on the selectivity of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts in the benzene hydrogenation reaction [11–13]. However, these reports concern most of all catalysts prepared by means of impregnation techniques. There have been also several interesting contributions on Ni–Cu–Al catalysts from coprecipitated hydrotalcite-like precursors and their assessment in other hydrogenation reactions [14–17]. However, to the best of our knowledge, there have been no studies on coprecipitated Ni–Cu–Al systems in terms of the benzene to cyclohexane hydrogenation. The contributions dealing with benzene hydrogenation on Ni and Ni–Cu catalysts focus on selectivity towards cyclohexane and methane [5,18]. The problem of other byproducts formed in benzene to cyclohexane hydrogenation reaction (MCP, MCH) has been discussed in literature very sparsely. The main goal of this contribution is to determine the effect of Cu addition on catalytic and physicochemical properties of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalysts for benzene hydrogenation prepared via co-precipitation route. The catalytic features (activity and selectivity) of several systems with a various Cu/Ni ratio have been compared and the modifier role in the benzene hydrogenation reaction has been tentatively proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts A series of model catalysts with a varying content of NiO (50–80wt%), CuO (0–36wt%) and Al2O3 was prepared. The catalysts precursors were obtained by means of co-precipitation from a solution of nickel nitrate (or nickel and copper nitrates), with a solution of sodium aluminate and sodium carbonate. The synthesis of precursors was carried out in a continuous mode, in the pH range 7–7.5 and at the temperature of 70–80°C. The precipitates were washed with distilled water to achieve filtrate conductivity below 300μS. After drying, the precursors were calcined at 400°C for 4h, formed into tablets and crushed. The fraction of 0.16–0.25mm was then sieved. 2.2 Methods The chemical composition of the catalysts was determined by means of the XRF method using a X’Unique II Philips spectrometer. The XRD measurements were performed on a PANalytical Empyrean system (Bragg‐Brentano geometry) equipped with a PIXcel3D detector, using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.542Å) and operating at 40kV and 40mA. The samples were scanned between 10<2θ<70°, with a step size 0.053° and time/step of 30s. The TPR measurements were performed using AutoChem 2950HP Micromeritics system. The catalysts samples were dried in a helium stream (20ml/min) at 200°C for 30min. The samples were then cooled to ambient temperature and activated with hydrogen (40ml/min), increasing the temperature with a rate 10°C/min. The reduction process was monitored using TCD by measuring the signal of water vapor that was a product of the reduction of copper and nickel oxides [19]. The specific surface area of the samples was determined with nitrogen adsorption isotherms at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (−196°C) and in the p/p0 range 0.05–0.3 using an ASAP 2050 Micromeritics analyzer. The nickel active surface area (SNi) was determined by hydrogen chemisorption at 35°C using an ASAP 2020 Micromeritics analyzer assuming Ni/H=1 chemisorption stoichiometry. The chemisorption experiments were carried out for the catalysts reduced with hydrogen at 400°C for 2h. The average nickel crystallites size was determined by means of two methods: • from the chemisorption measurements using the equations: SNi[m2/g]=nH ×NA ×Av ×m−1 ×XNi −1 (1) and dchem [nm]=6×103 ×γNi −1 ×SNi −1 (2), where: nH—H2 adsorbed [mol], NA—Nickel atom area (6.45×10−20 m2/atNi), AV—Avogadro number [at/mol], γNi—nickel density [g/cm3], SNi—active nickel surface area [m2/gNi], m—sample weight [g], XNi—nickel content [wt.%]. • from FWHM (full width at half maximum) of the peak at the 2θ angle of 44.4°, corresponding to the Ni (111) plane, according to the Scherrer equation dXRD =k×λ×(β×cos θ)−1 (3) [20], where: k—Scherrer equation constant (0.9), λ—wavelength of radiation [nm], β—line broadening of the XRD peak (FWHM) [rad], θ—diffraction angle [rad]. The surface composition of the catalysts was determined by the XPS method in a multichamber UHV Prevac system. The samples were reduced in hydrogen at 400°C for 2h before measurements. The XPS spectra were collected using Scienta R4000 photoelectron analyzer equipped with an aluminum anode (132W) and a CCD/MCP detector. The XPS spectra were processed using a CasaXPS application. The background signals in spectra were evaluated by means of Shirley algorithm, and the contents of particular elements with CasaXPS based on the peak areas, taking into account background and relative sensitivity factors (RSF) for particular lines. The energy scale of spectra was calibrated at a position of Ni2p 3/2Al peak for binding energy of metallic nickel that was 852.8eV. The high-resolution electron microscope Titan G2 60–300kV (FEI Company), equipped with the field emission gun (FEG) was used to display the catalysts. Microscopic studies of the catalysts were carried out at an accelerating voltage of the electron beam equal to 300kV. Phase separation (Cu, Ni and Al2O3) was performed with the FFT by using a masking available in the Gatan Digital Micrograph software package. On the basis of the FFT generated from HRTEM images of the reduced catalysts, individual phases with various crystallographic orientation derived from copper and nickel phase were identified. The experimental setup for measurements of benzene hydrogenation rate and selectivity is presented in Supporting Information. The key element is a gradientless reactor [21], operating at atmospheric pressure. The reactor was fed with an oxygen-free hydrogen stream, saturated in a thermostatic vessel with benzene or benzene/cyclohexane vapors. The reaction products were separated from the effluent gas and then analyzed by means of refractometry and chromatography. The benzene hydrogenation rate was determined in the temperature range 180–220°C at space velocities (4–6Ndm3/h) of reaction mixture (C6H6/C6H12/H2 [% mol]: 10/0/90) at the degree of conversion of ca. 50%. The evaluation of the reaction selectivity was carried out at space velocity 4Ndm3/h at the temperature 260°C, feeding the reactor with hydrogen saturated with benzene/cyclohexane vapors of the ratio close to equilibrium value. This approach allowed the measurements at a constant benzene/cyclohexane ratio, independently of the catalytic activity (the main reaction was in equilibrium, only side reactions occurred). The reaction selectivity was expressed as a ratio of the byproducts formation rate (MCP or MCH) to the benzene hydrogenation rate; rMCP/rC6H6 and rMCP/rC6H6 respectively. The catalysts were activated with hydrogen during heating up to 400°C and then stabilized for 4h. The temperature was then decreased to 180°C and the reactor was fed with the reaction mixture. Upon reaching of the operating conditions, the liquid products were condensed and their composition was analyzed using a Shimadzu 2010Plus GC. The catalysts were stabilized for 1h before each activity and selectivity measurements. The stability of the catalytic activity and selectivity of the copper-free (0Cu/Al2O3) and Ni–Cu/Al2O3 (0.25Cu/Al2O3) catalysts was determined in an analogous way by monitoring these parameters for 24h. 3 Results The XRF results of the chemical composition and the physicochemical features of the catalysts under study such as specific surface area, Ni surface area and average nickel crystallite size determined by means of XRD (dXRD) and chemisorption methods (dchem) are presented in Table 1 . The results confirm a good agreement between actual and nominal composition and indicate that a series of catalysts with a various Cu/Ni ratio and almost the same Al2O3 content were prepared. They reveal that the specific surface area and Ni surface area of catalysts depend on Cu/Ni ratio. Both were found to decrease with the increasing Cu/Ni ratio, albeit for the Ni surface area this trend was more distinct as can be observed from a decrease of the chemiosorbed hydrogen on the catalyst surface (Fig. 1 ). The data in Table 1 indicate some discrepancy between the average Ni crystallite size determined by both methods used. The chemisorption measurements suggest a strong increase of the Ni crystallite size with the increasing Cu content. For the 0.67Cu/Al2O3 catalyst the average Ni crystallite size is more than 6-fold greater than for the reference Ni/Al2O3 copper-free catalyst. This value determined by means of the XRD method increases much more slowly. For Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with the Cu/Ni ratio is up to 0.25, the average Ni crystallite size is on a level (4.8–5.3nm) similar to that for the reference catalyst and only for the catalysts with the highest Cu content the Ni crystallites growth to ca. 8.3nm can be observed. Diffractograms of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . They reveal a set of bands characteristic for the crystalline NiO phase (ICDD 4-11-9041) as indicated by the presence of reflections at 2θ angles: 37.3°, 43.5° and 62.8°. The diffraction lines corresponding to the CuO phase (ICDD 18-1548) at 2θ angles: 35.6° and 38.8° were identified only in the case of the catalyst with the highest amount of copper oxide (36wt%). Having in mind the partial overlapping of broad reflection lines from CuO and NiO phases, the presence of CuO phase only in case of 0.67Cu/Al2O3 may also suggest that copper oxide is very well dispersed within the catalyst. Broad diffraction lines indicate small NiO crystallites in the range 4–8nm. The TPR curves are shown in Fig. 3 . In the case of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst there are two reduction bands, which can be assigned to two different NiO forms. The first one, in the temperature range 200–280°C with a maximum of the reduction rate at 250°C is characteristic for so called free NiO [22]. The second broad band in the temperature range 300–600°C with a maximum at 410°C corresponds to the reduction of Ni oxides species which interact strongly with the Al2O3 support. The reduction of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalysts proceeds in a different way compared to the reference copper-free catalyst. The incorporation of CuO results in appearance of an intensive low-temperature band in the range 150–200°C and with a maximum of the reduction rate at 175°C that is characteristic for dispersed CuO species [23,24]. An increase of the CuO content leads also to a split of the band into two bands of lower intensity. This may be attributed to the reduction of mixed oxides CuO–NiO systems. The maximum of the first band is shifted towards lower temperatures, in contrast to the second band that is shifted towards higher temperatures. This can be linked with the presence of stoichiometric and non-stoichiometric NiO–Al2O3 phases with a various Ni/Al ratio as suggested by other authors [25,26]. For the 0.67Cu/Al2O3 catalyst two CuO reduction bands occur with a similar temperature of reduction rate maxima (133 and 152°C). This split of the CuO reduction bands with the increasing CuO content can be explained by the presence of different CuO forms on the catalysts surface [27,28] e.g. accessible highly dispersed or bulk CuO [29]. The XPS analysis of the surface composition reveals that both Ni and Cu are present in different forms on the catalysts surface. Similarly to observations of other authors [30–32], the presence of three states of nickel and two states of copper was found as indicated in Table 2 . In the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst there is only 32% of nickel atoms in the Ni0 form. The participation of Ni0 on the catalyst surface increases with the increasing Cu content (up to 20wt% CuO). However, independently of the CuO content, the share of Cu0 atoms on the catalyst surface is constant at the level of ca. 75%. A comparison of the Cu/Ni molar ratio both on the catalyst surface and in the bulk of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalysts is presented in Fig. 4 . It can be concluded that with the increasing CuO content the enrichment of the catalyst surface with copper during reduction occurs. The results presented are in agreement with other reports [33–35], showing such enrichment of the surface with copper upon increasing the Cu/Ni molar ratio. The copper segregation to the surface of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalysts may be one of reasons for the discrepancy between the average nickel crystallite size measured by means of hydrogen chemisorption and from XRD line broadening effect. The enrichment of the surface with copper results in a lower amount of chemisorbed hydrogen [13]. The second reason for the abovementioned discrepancy may be the polycrystallinity of Ni particles and their tendency for agglomeration. The nickel crystallites inside the agglomerates are not available for hydrogen and thus are “invisible” for the chemisorption method. They can be, however, well identified by means of the XRD method. In consequence, the size of Ni crystallites estimated by XRD is smaller than by sorption techniques. An advantage of the latter method is a possibility of the characterization of only surface Ni crystallites, easily available for reagents and taking an actual part in surface catalytic processes occurring. Similar discrepancies resulting from the polycrystallinity have been reported and explained by other authors [36,37]. An effect of the modifier content on a relative reaction rate is illustrated in Fig. 5 . An addition of small amounts of CuO results in some increase of the activity, but the range of this beneficial effect depends on the temperature. Thus, at 180°C this effect is observed for the CuO content in the range 0–5.4wt%, whereas at 220°C it is up to ca.18wt% CuO. Upon addition of larger amounts of the modifier the activity at the temperature range 180–220°C was found to decrease to the level of 40–50% as compared to the reference catalysts. The effect observed can be explained by the decreasing chemisorption of hydrogen with the increasing Cu content [33]. For catalysts containing more than 20wt% CuO a decrease of the observed activity is due to smaller nickel surface for the reactants in consequence of Ni–Cu interactions [38]. Similar observations concerning the temperature and copper effects on the benzene hydrogenation activity have been reported by Barneveld and Ponec [39]. For Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalysts with 5 and 10wt% CuO the activity was found to decrease in the temperature range 200–220°C. On the other hand, at temperatures above 220°C the Ni–Cu/Al2O3 systems exhibited higher activity due to the suppressed formation of carbon deposits leading to the deactivation of the nickel catalyst. Fig. 6 shows an effect of the CuO content on relative selectivities, expressed as a ratio of reaction rates towards both byproducts (rMCP or rMCH) to benzene hydrogenation rate. Detailed results of measurements of MCH and MCP concentrations in condensates are presented in Table S1 in Supporting information. As can be observed, the increasing CuO content decreases rMCP and thus increases the catalyst selectivity towards MCP, with practically no effect on the selectivity towards MCH. The best selectivity of the benzene hydrogenation reaction was achieved for the catalysts containing 10–20wt% CuO. The comparison of the activity and selectivity changes during operation of the reference catalyst and the system with the highest initial activity (0.25Cu/Al2O3) is presented in Fig. 7 a and b, respectively. In case of both catalysts the initial phase (appx. 5h) is a stabilization period with a sharp decrease of the activity by at least 60% and ca. 50% for the 0Cu/Al2O3 and 0.25Cu/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively. Further activity drop is significantly smaller and the activity is stable after the test duration of ca. 10–12h. The character of selectivity changes, expressed as a ratio of the MCP or MCH formation rate to benzene formation rate, is for both catalysts (0Cu/Al2O3 and 0.25Cu/Al2O3) similar to changes of benzene to cyclohexane hydrogenation rate. As it results from Fig. 7b an effect of a decrease of relative formation rates of side products upon copper modification is stable in time. Further analysis about the morphology of both samples was carried out by TEM. Fig. 8 shows HR-TEM images for reduced catalysts (respectively 0Cu/Al2O3 and 0.25Cu/Al2O3) and Fig. 9 shows HR-TEM images of these catalysts after 24h TOS. It could be observed that for 0Cu/Al2O3 catalyst the Ni surface species are around the amorphous alumina, which facilitates reaction between reactants and the active sites. In the case of 0.25Cu/Al2O3 catalyst HR-TEM images shows the occurrence of wide Cu islands and only a minor amount of well crystallized Ni species. According to the HR-TEM images it may be concluded that surface segregation take place even during activation of oxide form of catalyst and it is relatively intense. The occurrence the copper surface segregation may modifies the nickel active sites and thus limitation byproducts of benzene hydrogenation. HR-TEM images of these catalysts after 24h TOS shows Ni and Cu surface species randomly disturbed on amorphous alumina, but it could be observed a minor amount of well crystallized Ni species. 4 Discussion The incorporation of Cu into Ni/Al2O3 catalysts remarkably influences their physicochemical and catalytic properties. The phase composition analysis of the oxide forms of catalysts revealed the presence of the CuO phase only in the catalyst with the highest promoter content. These results find confirmation in other literature reports [16,28], where CuO reflections were observed only for samples with CuO content over 30wt% [16]. Moreover, in the case of Ni‐Cu/Al2O3 catalysts the CuO phase could be identified if the content was >18wt% [28]. No CuO diffraction lines in the case of catalysts with a lower promoter content can be explained by its high dispersion. The reduction of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts is dependent on many factors, including the preparation method, nickel content and presence of promoters. The extensive studies on the reducibility of Ni catalysts (from coprecipitated precursors) with a various nickel content have been reported by Li and Chen [40]. The authors demonstrated the presence of three NiO species with different reducibility. Salagre et al. [41] confirmed the presence of stoichiometric and non-stoichiometric NiO–Al2O3 phases in catalysts prepared by precursors calcination at 350°C. Moreover, differences in NiO reducibility due to the preparation method, discussed by Akande et al. [42] for Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were assigned to the different impact of NiO–Al2O3 interactions. The presence of additives influences the reduction of NiO via changes of the hydrogen dissociation rate, stability of Ni–O bonds as well as changes of Ni-support interactions [43,44]. As can be concluded from Fig. 4, the addition of CuO has a complex influence on the reduction of catalyst prepared using coprecipitation technique. Upon increasing the CuO content a low-temperature band assigned to the “free NiO” reduction together with a CuO reduction band appeared. The observed split of a high-temperature reduction band for support-bound NiO may be correlated with the influence of easily reducible CuO on NiO shares in NiO–Al2O3 phases with a various Ni/Al ratio [25,26,45]. A decrease of the NiO reduction temperature in the presence of CuO [23,46] can be explained by a spillover effect of atomic hydrogen [47] formed via the dissociative adsorption of hydrogen on the metallic Cu surface. The increasing content of Cu leads to a decrease of the specific and nickel surface areas. The remarkable decline of the nickel surface area arises from diminishing of the chemisorbed hydrogen amount upon increasing of the promoter content. A decrease of the hydrogen chemisorption is often explained by enrichment of the catalysts surface with copper [37,48,49]. Due to lower thermodynamic free energy [50] Cu occupies surface sites of Ni‐Cu systems, thus hampering the hydrogen sorption. It has been also suggested that the CuO content influences the presence of various types of surface sites available for the hydrogen adsorption [35]. Much smaller changes of the average Ni crystallite size were found by means of the XRD line broadening method. This finding together with the enrichment of the catalysts surface with copper indicates the surface segregation phenomenon, widely discussed in literature [51–53]. Detailed calculations based on the solid solution theory have been presented by Burton and Hyman [53], where the nickel atoms concentration in the Ni–Cu surface layer was calculated according to the Eq. (1): (4) X Ni S = ( X Ni b X Cu b ) e − Δ F/RT where XNi s—nickel surface concentration, XNi b—nickel bulk concentration, XCu b—copper bulk concentration, ΔF—driving force of surface segregation. Similar calculations of the surface composition of Ni–Cu alloys at low Cu content have been reported by Tománek et al. [54]. Moreover, the copper segregation effect is often observed for supported Ni–Cu catalysts prepared by various methods [55–58]. The increasing amount of CuO was found to influence the activity of the catalysts. A decrease of the catalytic activity was observed for catalysts containing above 20wt% CuO. According to van der Planck and Sachtler [59], this effect can be rationalized by the copper surface segregation phenomenon, leading to “dilution” of the nickel surface concentration, on which the adsorption of reagents occurs. Analogous observations have been made by other authors for the methane steam reforming reaction [48,60]. The incorporation of copper results in the enrichment of the catalysts surface with copper, decrease of the hydrogen chemisorption and in consequence the activity deterioration. The CuO addition causes also a decrease of the MCP and MCH content in the reaction products, and thus enhances the selectivity towards cyclohexane. In the literature data the selectivity issue in benzene hydrogenation usually concerns only methane. As an example, van Barneveld and Ponec [39], being aware of the formation of various byproducts such as pentane, MCP, isobutane, toluene, xylene, do not analyze the effect of copper on their presence and amount. Martin et al. also neglect the selectivity towards other side-reactions and an increase of the selectivity towards cyclohexane on Ni–Cu catalysts is ascribed to the suppression of benzene to methane hydrogenolysis reaction at temperatures above 240°C [61]. 5 Conclusions An increase of the Cu content in Ni/Al2O3 catalysts does not result in substantial structural differences compared to the copper‐free reference catalyst. The influence of the modifier, however, is revealed in reducibility as well as in changes of textural and catalytic properties. The increase of the CuO content results in appearance of the low‐temperature reduction band and a shift of the maximum reduction rate towards lower temperatures. The introduction of CuO into Ni/Al2O3 catalysts resulted in a decrease of the specific surface area and nickel surface area compared to the reference catalyst. The studies of catalytic properties of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 systems revealed that, at the CuO content in the range 10–17wt% CuO, catalysts exhibiting much better selectivity and a slightly lower activity in the benzene hydrogenation reaction. For catalysts with such modifier content a decrease of MCP and MCH byproducts by, respectively 70% and 10% was observed. Moreover, the introduction of CuO in the range 5.4–17wt%, depending on the reaction temperature, enhanced the catalytic activity. However, above 20wt% CuO the activity was found to decrease considerably. coredata.dc:description: The effect of a copper modifier on physicochemical properties of coprecipitated precursors and final Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalysts for benzene to cyclohexane hydrogenation was investigated. Based on the studies of physicochemical properties, the influence of copper on the catalytic activity and selectivity of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 systems was discussed. The addition of copper resulted in a decrease of the specific and nickel surface area, improvement of the selectivity and a slight decrease of the benzene hydrogenation activity compared to the reference catalyst. A decrease of methylcyclopentane and methylcyclohexane by-products formation on the surface of Ni–Cu/Al2O3 catalyst containing 10–17wt% CuO by, respectively, 70% and 10% was observed. The results reveal a distinct, beneficial effect of the Ni/Al2O3 modification by copper on the catalyst selectivity. However, this effect depends on temperature and is limited to ca. 20wt% CuO, above this content the activity was found to decrease considerably.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of copper on benzene hydrogenation to cyclohexane over Ni/Al2O3 catalyst
